text: all right our white bean ragout we're
going to use some Italian cannellini
beans all right I'm gonna drain those
those are 2 12 ounce jars I'm gonna
drain and rinse those I got my mirepoix
my carrot celery onion and a little bit
of tomato product I'm using what's
called a pepper nada I'll explain that
later so for the onion I'm going to do a
large dice maybe about quarter-inch
pieces okay
ideally I want the veggies about the
same size as the white bean I think
that's a nice professional look when the
veggies that are garnishing something
are the same size so I'm gonna try to
get these in about quarter-inch cubes
which is really close to the size of
those white cannellini beans all right
I'm the same with the celery so once my
mirepoix and mere applies just the fancy
culinary term for the aromatic veggies
carrots celery onion
once my mirepoix is chopped we are gonna
sweat that or saute it in a medium heat
pan here's a 4 quart pot so I put a
couple of gloves of olive oil in there
about 2 tablespoons and on medium heat I
just want you to sweat those down for
about 5 minutes before we add anything
else okay you don't need to put color on
them I don't want them brown really
all right so about 5-6 minutes on a
medium heat and those will just start to
soften and just start to get tender now
at that point 5 minutes later I'm gonna
add 3 cloves of chopped garlic I did not
use the press this time just chopped it
with a knife okay cuz that a stir now
while that garlic is flavoring that
olive oil and mirepoix mixture I'm gonna
go grab my salt and pepper this time I
decided to go with a ground black pepper
another variation on this if you want to
use a red pepper flake really nice
little spicier or combination so
whatever you like two really nice size
pinches of salt and this is definitely a
dish you got a taste and adjust the salt
later those white beans really they're
bland to begin with and they really suck
up a lot of salt so make sure you're
tasting this as you go as far as an herb
here I'm going to go real simple
instead of adding a whole bunch of
different dry herbs I'm going to use my
famous herb de Provence you've heard me
talk about this in other Clips probably
that's that southern French herb mix
rosemary savory marjoram chervil a
little lavender beautiful with bean with
beans and dish like this perfect choice
so I must earn my about a half a
teaspoon herb de Provence and that's
pretty much it for flavorings now what
we're going to do before we add the
beans we are going to simmer this with
just enough chicken stock to cover
alright I don't want this to be too
soupy you guys see later when I label
this on the plate how it kind of spreads
out a little bit but it's not really too
loose so just barely cover that and
simmer that for five minutes and then
you're gonna add your beans so we're
gonna give that a little head start with
the chicken stock again just enough to
cover and then you're gonna add your
beans now be gentle don't be crushing
these beans alright if you want to look
nice you want to leave the beans nice
and whole and then the last of our
ingredients here 1 bay leaf that was
kind of a small one but that's fine and
two nice rounded spoons of any kind of
tomato product now I'm use it what's
called a peperonata which is just kind
of a roasted red pepper and tomato sauce
any kind of diced tomato of a can hey if
you got a fresh tomato from the garden
chop that up throw it in be beautiful
but that little bit of tomato nice
little acid counterbalancing the
sweetness of the mirepoix I think it's a
nice nice combination now I just want
you to put that on low and just simmer
it till everything is tender and all
those flavors has come together maybe
10-15 minutes all right after 10-15
minutes I checked now the carrot is
probably going to take the longest so I
made sure that was tender and it was I
shave a whole bunch of parsley and I
shave I just taken a sharp knife like a
45-degree angle and just slicing the the
leaves right off the stems I don't pick
it all apart takes too long this little
chef's trick so I shaved all leaves off
and just gave that a nice chop and again
don't be too fine on it I want to see
some I want to see some parsley when I
stir this in I don't want it all just
like a dust and you notice I'm using a
folding technique here because I don't
want to break up the beans I'm
to be just just come together without I
don't want any crushed beans I got I
wanted to look like a bean soup alright
to finish this off I put a couple ladles
on a plate here and again check out the
consistency not too soupy just enough
liquid to moisten it all and just make
it beautiful underneath this roasted
lamb shank is what I served it with this
time anything tastes good on top of this
stuff believe me half chicken grilled a
piece of fish almost anything so I hope
you give this a try
enjoy
